Figure 1. Schematic diagram of the melatonin biosynthetic pathway.

Figure 2. Construction and validation of pUC57-melatonin synthesis plasmid. A. Schematic diagram. B. Plasmid digestion and nucleic acid electrophoresis. C. RT-qPCR analysis of these four synthetic genes, normalized to 16S rRNA. All experiments were performed in triplicate.

Figure 3. Yield analysis of melatonin synthesis by engineered bacteria. A.HPLC-MS chromatogram showing a peak consistent with the melatonin standard. B. Standard curve of melatonin standard. C.  HPLC chromatogram of purified melatonin product.

Figure 4. Optimization of induction and substrate conditions for melatonin production. A. Effect of IPTG concentration on melatonin yield. B. Effect of tryptophan concentration on melatonin yield. All experiments were performed in triplicate.
Figure 5. Concentration changes of melatonin and intermediate metabolites over time.

Figure 6. Expression and Purification of HsAANAT. A. Schematic diagram of the recombinant plasmid. B. Plasmid digestion and nucleic acid electrophoresis. C. SDS-PAGE analysis of HsAANAT:Purificatied and concentrated soluble protein.

Figure 7. Catalytic mechanism of HsAANAT. A. Proposed catalytic mechanism of HsAANAT. B. Effect of acetyl-CoA concentration on the catalytic reaction. C. Molecular docking results of HsAANAT with Ac-CoA and 5-HT, showing the lowest-energy binding conformation.
Figure 8. Analysis of molecular dynamics simulation trajectories.

Figure 9. Optimization of the model reaction for HsAANAT-catalyzed conversion of 5-HT to NAS. A. Schematic diagram of the model reaction system. B. HPLC-MS identification spectrum of NAS. C. Effect of different cosolvents on the reaction. D. Optimization of acetyl-CoA concentration. E. Effect of pH on enzyme activity. F. Comparison of different buffer systems. G. Optimization of enzyme concentration. H. Optimization of substrate concentration. All experiments were performed in triplicate.

Figure 10. Deep learning–guided engineering of HsAANAT. A. Relative activity of AANAT mutants (all experiments were performed in triplicate). B. Distance between the substrate (5-HT) and residue F56 as a function of simulation time. C. Distance between the substrate (5-HT) and residue F188 as a function of simulation time.
Figure 11. Effect of wild-type HsAANAT and mutant strain M2 on melatonin yield.
Figure12. Mechanism of Temperature Control System at 37℃, 42℃ respectively.

Figure 13. Plasmid construction and functional validation of the temperature-controlled reporter system. A. Schematic diagram. B. Plasmid digestion and nucleic acid electrophoresis. C. Transformation plate of E. coli BL21 with the reporter plasmid. D. Bacteria harboring the reporter system cultured at different temperatures. From left to right: control (empty vector), 37°C, 37→42°C shift, and 42°C. All experiments were performed in triplicate.
Figure 14. Relative Expression Levels of Fluorescent Proteins under Different Temperature Conditions.All experiments were performed in triplicate.
Figure 15. Functional Diagram of the Acoustic System.
Figure 16. Constructions of pET28a-MscL and pET28a-Acoustic controlled plasmid
Figure 17. Validation of the expression of MscL

Figure 18. Functional analysis of acoustic-controlled system. A.OD600 change in MscL(+) and MscL(-) group. B.Fluorescence Intensity(FI) change in MscL(+) and MscL(-) group. C. qPCR analysis showing relative NhaR expression in both groups.
Figure 19. Exploration of the functionality of acoustic system

Figure 20. Schematic diagram of the red-light-regulated switch. In the dark, Cph8 activates, the expression of the repressor protein CI, which blocksK1FRexpression and consequently prevents transcription of the downstreamPk1fP_{k1f}Pk1f​target gene (GFP). Under 635 nm red light, Cph8 is inactivated, stopping the expression of CI. This de-represses the downstreamK1FRgene from thePλP_{λ}Pλ​promoter, K1FR then activates thePk1fP_{k1f}Pk1f​promoter, driving target gene (GFP) expression.

Figure 21. Functional validation of the red light-regulated switch. A. Changes in OD600 of the engineered bacteria under dark and red light conditions. B. Changes in GFP fluorescence intensity after red light induction. C. Reproducibility test: cycles of 6 h red light exposure followed by 6 h darkness. All experiments were repeated three times.

Figure 22. Diagram of the Bxb1-RDF mechanism. A. Design of the temperature-controlled Bxb1 system. B. Flip-flop reporter mechanism: Bxb1 inverts the promoter betweenattPandattBsites, activating sfGFP expression. When Bxb1-RDF is expressed, the promoter is inverted back, switching expression to mRFP1

Figure 23. Bxb1-RDF System Validation. A. temperature-controlled Bxb1 plasmid digestion and nucleic acid electrophoresis. B.mRFP-attP-attB-sGFP Plasmid digestion and nucleic acid electrophoresis.C. Expression of Bxb1 and Bxb1-RDF under different temperature conditions.

Figure 24. Fluorescence Signal Detection of Bxb1/Bxb1-RDF & Flipping system. A. Fluorescence signals detected under different culture temperatures. B. Changes in fluorescence signals during temperature-shift culture.

Figure 25. Hypoxia-Activated Toxin-Antitoxin System. TheMazEgene is regulated by thePfnrP_{fnr}Pfnr​promoter, while the_FNr_andMazFgenes are constitutively expressed under the T7 promoter. In a low-oxygen environment, FNr dimerizes and activatesPfnrP_{fnr}Pfnr​. This results in the simultaneous expression of the antitoxin (MazE) and the toxin (MazF), which form a complex. This complexation mechanism enables the engineered bacteria to survive under hypoxia.

Figure 26. Validation of the hypoxia-inducible reporter system. A. Schematic diagram of the hypoxia-inducible promoter. B. Plasmid digestion and nucleic acid electrophoresis. C. Engineered bacteria cultured under hypoxic and normoxic conditions. D. Relative GFP expression under hypoxia versus normoxia.
Figure 27. Effect of the toxin-antitoxin system on bacterial growth. A.Bacterial growth with and without IPTG induction. B. Changes in OD₆₀₀ under conditions with and without IPTG induction.

Figure 28. Tryptophan auxotrophic strain. A. Schematic diagram. B. Growth Profile on M9 Solid Media. The engineered strain showed no growth on tryptophan-deficient M9 solid medium (left), while normal growth was observed on tryptophan-supplemented medium (right). C. Changes in OD₆₀₀.
Figure 29. Lyophilized powder of engineered bacteria.

Figure 30. Functional characterization of the lyophilized engineered strain. A. Viability assessment by plate counting. B. Growth curves of the engineered strain before and after lyophilization. C. qPCR analysis using cDNA from the lyophilized engineered bacteria as template, normalized to 16S rRNA. D. HPLC chromatogram of melatonin . All experiments were performed in triplicate.
